awd_abstract_narration:
The research activities enabled by this award include fundamental geochronological research on landscape forming processes in river and dune landscapes over a range of environments from the humid mid-continent to the Great Basin of North America, to river systems in China and South Africa. These collaborative projects address the impacts of human-landscape interaction, natural hazards, and sustainability and thereby have significant potential for informing decisions regarding policy and management. This funding supports a full time technician for the Desert Research Institute E.L. Cord Luminescence Laboratory (DRILL). The technician is critical to better serving the user community, training of visiting students and scientists, maintenance of the DRILL, and timely completion of projects. The DRILL is dedicated to luminescence research, which is a geological dating technique that enables geochronologists to define the burial age of sediments and some artifacts.  This award also facilitates fundamental research in luminescence dating and training of visiting students and scientists.  

The goal of this project is to farther develop the DRI Luminescence Laboratory (DRILL) to better serve the geochronology user community and to become a center of learning about luminescence through the support of a full time technician. The research activities enabled by this award include fundamental research on landscape evolution and process geomorphology in addition to technique development including directly dating volcanic glass and the extension of luminescence data to understanding geomorphic processes such as sediment transport in rivers and particle mixing on hillslopes. The goals are to better serve those needing luminescence dating in their projects and training the next generation of luminescence practitioners.

inst.inst_name: Nevada System of Higher Education, Desert Research Institute

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The goal of this project was to facilitate optimal and efficient operation of advanced instrumentation, analytical protocol development, and user training in geochronology for Earth sciences as well as conduct cutting-edge research. Support from this grant has significantly broadened the research capacity of the Desert Research Institute Luminescence Dating Research Laboratory (DRILL) in Earth and Archaeological sciences. Activities included fundamental geochronological research on landscape forming processes in North America, northern Tibet, Saudi Arabia, Australia, India, Canada, Africa, New Zealand and Antarctica. Our luminescence chronologies have provided constraints on fault slip rates to inform continental seismic histories, as well as time constraints on climate-driven processes such as river flooding, aggradation and incision, dune migration and stabilization, and lake and sea level fluctuations. In addition to providing an age constraint on a previously unidentified marine incursion during MIS 13 in northern Tasmania, development of novel thermally-transferred luminescence dating techniques have provided the first age constraints on some of the oldest aeolian and coastal dune deposits in Tasmania.

Significant research developments in archaeology have emerged through support from this grant. Luminescence chronologies for the Cooper Ferry site and the Buhl Burial site in Idaho have provided insights into early human migration and settlement in the Americas. This grant has also supported methodological developments in luminescence dating of rocks and building materials that have expanded DRILL’s capacity to date both historical and pre-historical archaeological sites and features. These collaborative projects address the long-term impacts of climate change and natural hazards on people and infrastructure and have significant potential for informing decisions regarding policy and management.

BROADER IMPACTS

This project aimed to improve the quality of student education, research, and research training, increase access to luminescence dating technology to geochronology users, increase the number of trained users of luminescence dating technology, and broaden participation of women and minorities in STEM fields. This grant supported training for 8 graduate students in geochronology and 2 Assistant Professors. It also supported the training of 11 student hourly employees from diverse backgrounds in sample preparation protocols and lab workflow management and provided them with work experience in STEM. During NSF support, Neudorf has been promoted from Rank 1 Research Scientist to Rank 2 Assistant Research Professor at DRI. Research supported by this award has resulted in 15 peer-reviewed manuscripts, 19 conference abstracts and 37 project reports.

This grant supported educational initiatives on several fronts for students and researchers at all levels of experience. Hands-on training in luminescence sample preparation, measurement and analysis was provided on-site at DRILL to visiting students and researchers, and virtual seminars and tutorials were provided for remote participants. Educational blogs and research updates were posted several times a year on the DRILL lab website and DRI Luminescence twitter page. An invited talk entitled: “Illuminating the Past – Luminescence Dating and its Applications” was presented by Neudorf for the Geography Colloquium, Department of Geography, University of Nevada, Reno. An educational podcast was also recorded by Neudorf for the National Park Servicefor the project: “Adapting luminescence dating techniques to derive and preserve the chronology of adobe building construction in North America”.

This grant supported initiatives to benefit the broader scientific community. This grant supported progress toward the development of a new online data repository for luminescence data. This grant also supported Neudorf as co-coordinator of the New World Luminescence Dating Portable Gamma Spectrometer Calibration Initiative held in Grand Junction, Colorado, Oct. 19-20th, 2019, which drew luminescence practitioners from across the US together to calibrate instrumentation. NSF supported planning and organizing of the 15th New World Luminescence Dating Workshop (NWLDW 2024), hosted at DRI, June 11-14. This workshop provided a friendly and inclusive venue for students to interact with experts in Archaeology, Earth science and Geochronology, and featured 39 in-person and remote presentations from local and international scholars.


Last Modified: 06/26/2024
Modified by: Christina M Neudorf
